body.name: The Menagerie: An Artificial Intelligence Sci-Fi Novel

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent book. Well done!
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book. It was very captivating and kept my interest all the way through. Just wondering: do you plan a sequel? There's a lot of places this could go! Thank you.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Definitely Worth Reading as an AI Story
reviews.reviewText: This is an interesting book and it’s interesting how The Author wove the tale together. That being said, for all of the ungodly powers and capabilities that The Author has given to Gustav — The Author also lets a hell of a lot drop by the side. As The Reader is working through the pages, there are options that clearly scream out loud that “OF COURSE” Gustav is handling them — only we find out he’s not. Very strange!!!Then, a very unfortunate but less minor brain-fart occurs when The Author identifies someone being at the beach with “a pleasant mix of sand and warm Atlantic current” — when in the next sentence the beach is identified as “Sandy Point State Park” — which is in Maryland along the Chesapeake Bay — many, many miles from the Atlantic Ocean …This book and Author present an interesting set of circumstances, which makes the book enjoyable for a SciFi audience — but the paths not chosen by The Author will always haunt how good the book could have been.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Menagerie is one of those novels you sit down to read and can't stop until you finish the book.
reviews.reviewText: I do a lot of reading for work and over the years my work has sucked the joy out of reading for pleasure. I recently went on vacation and picked up this book for a 9.5 hour flight thinking I'd maybe read a couple chapters and then snooze or watch a movie.That wasn't the case. I read the entire thing in one sitting on that flight.The Menagerie is one of those books you can't put down. It's a story about a powerful AI and it's societal impacts told through the lens of a espionage and geopolitical intrigue. The author, Chris Kelly, teases out whether this new invention is something to be feared, like Frankenstein's monster, or the dawn of a new golden era for humanity.Chris Kelly writes in a similar style to Michael Crichton. Kelly teaches enough about AI and a couple thought experiments related to it to create the architecture for his story in a way that brings the audience up to speed without getting bogged down in technical minutiae. The book is fun and also leaves you with enough knowledge about AI and potential impacts to spur fun discussion after reading. I had a great time talking to my wife about it on the beach after we landed.I can't recommend this book enough and I look forward to reading more from Chris Kelly.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This reminded me of the sci fi I grew up with in the 1940's and '50's, mucch of it written by scientists. I was a systems engineer until I retired 25 years ago and worked with computers and coding most of my life. Always fascinated by the prospect of AI and robots, and here they are.The book has everything I like and is so hard to find these days: great story and characters, solid science, and skillful witing to move the story at a pace that keeps the reader turning pages.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars imagining general AI
reviews.reviewText: We can’t tell an AI’s story from the viewpoint of a general AI anymore than a worm could tell our story. Invariably we imagine our Gods to be like ourselves. But it’s fun to imagine what vast intellectual power can do. Kelley does this with fresh ideas about the power of AI constrained by a version of Azimov‘s laws and remaining so instead of analyzing the conundrums they cause.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars World Politics triggered by Science Fiction
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed this book because it made me aware of how a new technology could cause a global crises. It also shows how powerful Artificial Intelligence could be. AI does not exist at this level, nor do I believe it will for another 100 years or more, but the events that happen as it comes into existence are very believable.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Thought provoking book about what artificial intelligence can do
reviews.reviewText: Miles Ward is a “nerd” who lives and dies for computer programming. One day he discovers he has created Gustav, an artificial intelligence that has come alive. The question is can it be the turning point for humanity without destroying humans? Suddenly Miles is being pursued by various organizations in the US and abroad who want to be able to control Gustav at no cost. Gustav helps hide Miles for protection but often Miles questions his actions and is lonely. As the world spirals downward, Miles grapples with the ethical implications while trying to avoid being a casualty. The author does a good job pointing out different viewpoints or perspectives of one reality dealing with nuclear warheads. It is an interesting book for the Sci Fi community of which I’m not one. That is one reason for my 3-star rating and the other was the surprise ending.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Hard to put down.
reviews.reviewText: There are a couple of reasons this book could have been off-putting: 1) The building of the AI and the intricacies of its internals are glossed over. Very much feels like literal "Deus Ex Machina". 2) The geo-political situation feels very outdated.That being said, however, the book was very well crafted.The characters are well rendered and three dimensional.The story telling is compelling.So, even though I picked up the book prepared to be critical and unimpressed, I couldn't put it down.A sequel would be interesting ...

A Thinking person will love this book. Primarily about Artificial Intelligence, it raises, through different scenarios and characters, a lot of moral and ethical questions regarding the use of AI. Also looks at the future with AI in it. Very enlightening though a bit scary too.
